data.title: Classic Film And TV Corner
data.text:
Many of you who know me know of my love for Audrey Hepburn. I love her as an actress and fashion icon, but I love her even more for who she was as a person in everyday life. Audrey was a tireless humanitarian working on behalf of UNICEF, compassionate, generous, sincere, courageous, down-to-earth, humble and… Continue reading Audrey Hepburn’s Top Four Film Performances

What I love most about Crimson Peak is that it is a meticulously crafted love letter to the Gothic genre and to classic era horror cinema. There are homages to The Innocents(the scene where Edith explores the house with her candlestick holder); The Changeling(the wheelchair and the ball scene); and Jane Eyre(the scene where Thomas says he would bleed… Continue reading Crimson Peak(2015): Del Toro’s Magnum Opus

Television audiences in the 1970's were lucky enough to be able to tune in weekly to some of the greatest detective series ever made: Columbo, The Sweeney, Kojak, The Streets Of San Francisco, Police Woman, The Rockford Files, Charlie's Angels, Van der Valk etc. One of the most beloved of the decade was Starsky &… Continue reading Starsky & Hutch(1975-1979)

Ida Lupino was a pioneer and a force of nature. She was the only female film director working in America from the late 1940's until the early 1960's. She also directed nearly a hundred television episodes. She wasn't the least bit interested in merely looking pretty and glamourous on screen. Ida had no qualms about… Continue reading Ida Lupino: Fearless Actress Turned Trailblazing Independent Director

More than fifty years on from her tragic and untimely death, the actress and producer Madhubala remains an icon of Indian cinema, and has become beloved by generations of film fans. Madhubala could do it all: drama, comedy, romance, musicals, historical epics. At the height of her fame during the 1950's she was the highest-paid… Continue reading Remembering Madhubala(1933-1969): Classic Era Bollywood’s Beloved Star

The multi-talented Judy Garland delivered so many magnificent screen performances during her years working in the film industry. One of her best and most touching performances as a dramatic actress can be found in the hidden gem The Clock, which was known as Under The Clock, when it was released here in the UK. The… Continue reading The Clock(1945)

Today would have been Norma Jeane's 98th Birthday. She was one of a kind and a trailblazer in many ways. I love her as an actress and a comedienne, but I love her most for who she was as a person. Marilyn was compassionate, kind, gentle, intelligent, intellectually curious, generous, sensitive, vulnerable, luminous, empathetic, brave,… Continue reading Remembering Marilyn Monroe At 98

Frankie And Johnny was directed and produced by Garry Marshall(Runaway Bride, Beaches)and followed in the wake of his box-office hit Pretty Woman(1990). Frankie And Johnny was written by Terence McNally who adapted the screenplay from his own off-Broadway stage play Frankie And Johnny In The Claire de Lune. The play opened in 1987 at New York's… Continue reading Frankie And Johnny(1991)

Few British films have ever been as violent or as shocking as Ealing Studios Second World War invasion thriller Went The Day Well?. Its brutality still horrifies and shocks eighty years on. If you're only familiar with Ealing's beloved comedy output of the 1940's and 1950's, then I guarantee you that this one will come… Continue reading Went The Day Well?(1942): Ealing Goes To War
